Content: Well, J.D. Vance warned us the other week about freedom of speech.
By that he meant censorship.
But there's another thing that happened last night
that makes me worry about freedom of speech
and about the whole democratic process.
It was an event that I was doing in Camborne in Cornwall last night
where a group called Antifa turned up.
Now, they have their origins in America
and they're more than happy to resort to violence.
Have a quick look at some of the Antifa protesters from last night.
Shame! Shame! Shame!
Who protects the fascist?
Who protects the fascist?
Shame on you! Shame on you!
You should be f***ing embarrassed!
Shame on you! Shame on you!
So let's be clear, these were masked protesters.
Members of the public were expected to walk through them.
Of course, what they were looking for was members of the public to react.
One member of the public who was there had his tooth knocked out.
But no arrests were made.
And no attempt was made by Devon and Cornwall police
to separate protesters out.
And prior to the event,
they'd made scores of phone calls to the venue saying,
cancel the event or there will be violence on your premises.
I've got to tell you something.
I'm a great believer in political protest.
You can stand there and shout, maybe chuck the odd egg.
All right?
Just about live with that.
What I thought, I think what happened last night
was closer to political terrorism
and quite extraordinary.
That Zoe Fox, Councillor Zoe Fox was there
and she was the Labour Mayor of Camborne up until last year.
I have written to the Home Secretary
and I will be actually writing to the Chief Constable
of Devon and Cornwall Police
complaining about their conduct.
You've seen loads of political protests over the years.
I just don't think people with masks
should be able to crowd round the entrance.
No.
What is a democratic event?
Yeah, I completely agree.
I mean, actually you couldn't see it very well on that clip.
No.
The clip I looked at earlier where they were masked.
They look very intimidating.
Nobody should be intimidated in attending a political event,
a public event.
If the police and the organisers, reform presumably,
have been in touch and liaised,
as you would always have to do for this sort of thing,
how many people do you expect?
Have you got adequate car parking, etc., etc.?
But if the venue had had warnings of violence,
I'm surprised that the police seem to think,
well, perhaps they don't mean it.
Well, it's this response to policing,
that we act when there's a problem,
rather than being preventative.
And they could have just read online
and have known what was going to happen.
Well, yes.
But I think there will have been people going to that,
as there would be to any political party meeting,
who might have gone,
oh, I'm not going to go through that.
Well, 100 people who'd bought tickets turned around and left.
I'm not a member of your party, Nigel, obviously.
No, sure.
I didn't expect you to be.
OK.
But, you know, everybody has got the right to do that.
And we're all used to it.
And, you know, I've been to a gazillion party conferences
where they're noisy and, you know, not very pleasant,
but not that level of intimidation to members of the public.
No.
In a village hall, I presume.
This is a...
Well, it was a...
In fact, it was a centre with a gymnasium,
a swimming pool.
There were actually young kids coming in and out.
So it's not...
What I mean is it's not a purpose-built conference centre
like you'd get at the Royal Labour or Torrid.
No.
I mean, my concern here is that if these people are allowed
to continue to behave like this,
and let's hope the Home Secretary does...
I mean, I think Antifa should be a banned organisation,
frankly, because of the fact they've used violence so repeatedly,
particularly all over America.
But otherwise, how do we conduct elections?
How do we have proper debate?
I think it's quite concerning.
We have, in this country, a serious...
And law enforcement have a serious blind spot
when it comes to far-left extremism.
As you say, Antifa, particularly in the United States,
are a violent leftist extremist organisation.
The journalist Andy Ngo, who's a very good friend of mine,
actually tried to kill him for reporting on their activities.
So, you know, this is not something that we can tolerate
in the short term without it escalating in the long term.
And we've seen this with other types of protests
over the last five years, that when you give them an inch,
it keeps going and going and going
until it's the destruction of property,
vandalism and eventually attacking people.
And no arrests!
No arrests!
And when you see the way that the police protest other protests,
where they're so heavy-handed,
and this is straightforward democratic interference.
And what's remarkable is that, you know,
for all of the talk in Parliament,
particularly in the Labour Party,
of how it's important for everybody to, you know,
be nice to one another,
and they would be very quick to jump on incitement
if it were from a right-wing party
towards somebody in the Labour Party.
But when an MP like Zahra Sultana is putting up posters of youth
that are really quite demonic-looking,
they have nothing to say about that.
And so, really, if the Labour Party,
you mentioned J.D. Vance's speech
and him talking about how the greatest threat to us
is the loss of our fundamental values in this country.
Well, diplomatically, in his relationship with Donald Trump,
if Keir Starmer doesn't take things like this seriously,
freedom of speech, the democratic process,
then that is not going to be very good
for our relationship with America in the long term.
No.
They are banning books in America, Emma.
What are they banning?
They're banning books in libraries, aren't they?
Children's books.
Oh, they're taking some children's books out of public libraries.
They're not banning them.
They're not banning them.
They're banning them from libraries.
They're not banning them or banning them,
but I know what you mean.
A spokesman for Devon and Cornwall police said,
police were aware of a political event
at the Cambrai Leisure Centre in Paul Cornwall.
Officers attended in order to ensure the safety of those present
and prevent any potential breach of the peace.
Well, sorry.
There were reports of minor issues that occurred
between protesters and counter-protesters
which were brought under control by officers.
No arrests were made.
What absolute cobblers.
There were no counter-protesters.
These were delegates coming to a conference
who'd paid money to be there.
Dear, oh, dear, oh, dear.
The What the Farage moment of the day is now
Winston Churchill portraits are being removed
from Parliament buildings.
And that over the last couple of years
goes along with William Gladstone,
Oliver Cromwell, Lord Liverpool,
Jigga Wellington, William Wilberforce,
Lord Salisbury, John Milton, Charles I,
and Queen Victoria and Prince Albert.
Do Labour hate our history that much?
26,000 works of art within the parliamentary estate
that anybody can choose to have,
and many of them ring the changes.
I mean, I don't know what your office accommodation is like.
Poor.
OK.
Well, maybe we could have a tiny picture.
We'll look for a Holbein.
Yeah.
But, you know, they are constantly churned around.
Under the previous government, there was a review,
I think it was 2022,
of the sort of works of art
that were being displayed in Parliament and public buildings,
because a lot of these are areas where the public go as well.
Yeah.
Yeah, Port Colour's house particularly.
Yes, exactly.
And Westminster Hall as well.
And, you know, so there was a review,
an audit, I think they called it,
of people or symbols, if you like, of slavery
or things that we might not be comfortable with anymore.
Yeah. Wow.
But I think to the idea that, you know,
they've taken down Churchill
and they've put him in a bunker somewhere,
they're just changing things around.
Well, there is.
I mean, it's rather,
it's sort of Diane Abbott in and Churchill out, really, isn't it?
Or am I being unfair?
You're not being unfair.
I mean, it's not arbitrary either.
The portraits that they've been removing
are portraits that were on that list.
And many of them were included on that list
for, you know, their links to slavery
for very tenuous reasons,
including, for some reason,
William Wilberforce,
who spearheaded the abolition of slavery.
Bizarre.
And the thing about Churchill is actually
that this is coming from a politically motivated,
ideologically motivated campaign
of defamation against a national hero.
One of the main things
that often gets brought up against him
is the Bengal famine,
which has been repeatedly
myth-busted
and shown to be completely factually false
by some of our most eminent historians,
including Churchill's biographer,
Andrew Roberts.
So I think what we're seeing
with the removal of these portraits
is very much in line with what we saw
during the campaign.
It's a trend.
How funny.
There is a large statue of Churchill.
There is.
There is for now.
Which keeps getting graffiti.
For now.
And attacked.
Well, it's Churchill out in Parliament,
but Churchill into the Oval Office.
So,
